p.s: In the given excerpt, the reader gets to know ana new, unknown side of Gatsby.
In the previous story, Gatsby is presented as a well-kept, mysterious man.
Nick for example perceives him as a person of some undefined consequence (p. 64, l. 14).
Even though Nick's opinion about Gatsby changes in chapter 4, when he tells him about his backstory, Nicks's previous view on him is still the same for other outsiders.
Nick has the strong impression that Gatsby is a man, who is picking his words with care (p. 50, ll. 9-10).

Even while telling Nick God's truth (p. 64, l. 30) the reader and Nick get no chance of seeing GatsbysGatsby's true emotions or intentions, as he still hides behind a fassadefacade, that he has build up around himself.
We can see this on p. 65 in ll. 3-5, where Nick thinks: and I knew why Jordan Baker had believed he was lying.He hurried the phrase [...].
Adding to this he wonders if there wasn't something a little sinister about him after all (p. 65, ll. 6-7), which shows, that he has problems with figuring Gatsby out.
This in the first chapters shown fassadefacade crumbles in the 5th chapter, which is especially highlighted in the given excerpt.
The reader observes Gatsby how he behaves, when he's not on behalf of his every word and more, as he is too nervous about seeing Daisy.
The impression that his thoughts are scattered is given.
In the course of the scene the reader can see Gatsby's poor attempt to gain control over his behaviour, when he tries to build up the mentioned fassadefacade again.
This action takes place on p. 84 in the line 38 where he was reclining against the mantelpiece in a strained counterfeit of perfect ease, even of boredom.

This attempt fails in knocking over a clock, which symbolises that his attempt to revive a past relationship, to reset the time, could be poorly and likely to collapse, which ll. 13-14 on p. 85 show us as well: I think we all believed for a moment that it had smashed in pieces on the floor.
Especially the narratorsnarrator's perspective of Nick lays out Gatsby's emotions in front of us, which weren't reachable before, showing us that Gatsby is a love-struck young man.
Nick's perspective tells us, that Gatsby's feelingfeelings are not only what he feels inside, but are visible from the outside.
In the excerpt he is like an open book, free for Nick to read.

It can be seen for example in the line glaring tragically into my eyes (p. 84, l. 16), or that he is pale as death, with his hands punged like weights in his pockets (p. 84, ll. 14-15) or furthermore the mention of his distraught eyes (p. 84, l. 30), his tense unhappy eyes (p. 85, l. 25) or the use of the word miserable when thinking of Gatsby in this scene (p. 85, l. 31).
The particular repeating of the feelings in his eyes tell us that they are most likely genuine.
Also significant is the use of contrasts in this scene, where there is for example a choke of murmur and part of a laugh (p. 84, l. 22), or a perfect ease and distraught eyes (p. 84 ll. 28-30).
This also can be seen in Daisy's behaviour, when she says she's awfully glad to see Gatsby again (p. 84, l. 24) or that she was sitting frightened but graceful (p. 85, l. 1).

They show us that the two characters can't decide between two emotions and also pretend to feel different as they really are, as for example Daisy's words awfully have ana negativnegative connotation and glad have ana positive connotation.
This undecivenessindecisiveness foreshadows the change of emotion and behaviour both figures have at the end of the excerpt.
Nick descirbes it as a change in Gatsby that was simply confounding and he glowed while a new well-being radiated from him (p. 87, ll. 13-15).

Also Daisy's behaviour has changed, because her face is smeared with tears of joy (p. 87, l. 11) and her voice is described as her throat, full of aching, grieving beauty, told only of her unexpected joy (p. 87, ll. 23-24).
Again, one can see the contrast of the words grieving and beauty.
They overcome the embarrassment in which Nick told Gatsby he was acting like a little boy and was being rude to Daisy (p. 86, ll. 8-9).
The result of this shifted mood can be seen when Nick tells us that Gatsby smiled like a weather man, like an estatic paron of recurrent light (p. 87, ll. 14-15).
Both Daisy and Gatsby seem to be happy at the end of the excerpt.
The last aspect that played a role in Gatsby's behaviour is the setting of the scene, which is Nick's house.
It is an unfamiliar surrounding for Gatsby which probably contributes to his nervousness.
It doesn't feel like a safe place in which he knows, what he can do or show to divert attention from the awkward situation.
